column4: just prefix statements with my nick and some punctuation; that should help
Standard etiquette yes.
please add the output from `dmesg ; cat /proc/interrupts' to that pastebin
http://pastebin.ca/1068608
sec
which applications are affected by this?  Are you using a default install without customisations to sound dialogues?  (i.e., PulseAudio)
Audacious and mplayer both suffer from it.
are web browsers with, say, a Java and/or Flash plugin, ever involved?
Firefox's flash also suffers but there the video and audio don't even synch as in mplayer.
As for sound dialogues customisations, I turned off system sounds.
I.e. login and logout sounds.
to be precise, if you _only_ use audacious [but no web browser or Java app], is the symptom exhibited?
Will test.
46 seconds in.
Audacious lasts about twice as long before cutting.
Will say when it continues.
and this is from a fresh boot?
Yup.
_without_ having opened a web browser.
Without having Firefox open.
Closed it when you said it.
do you still have the desktop cd handy?  if so, can you reproduce it from a fresh boot using it?
I have the desk-song continues-
I have the desktop CD yes.  Used it to reinstall Ubuntu earlier this evening.
ok, please boot from the desktop cd, install audacious and whatnot, and attempt to reproduce the issue running directly from the live cd
And it's cut at 1:50 again.
And song continues :)
And cut, this was short at 2:11, Either way, so boot from Live CD, install Audacious and Irssi and report back?
yes, please, thanks.
Okay, I'll be back in a few minutes.
Okay, currently on the live CD.
And currently playing the same song.
ok, let me know if the symptom is reproducible.
is the desktop cd you're using 8.04 or 8.04.1?
No idea.
lsb_release -r
sorry, lsb_release -d
Same.
ok, then it's definitely not a software regression
Aye.
check `dmesg' for any unusual output.
Define unusual output please.
anything along the lines of "codec timed out", etc.
it would appear via `dmesg|tail'
Nothing on the keyword 'codec'.
ok, I don't know how much further you want to chase the issue, which appears to be hardware-based.
Saw that coming.
if you want, you can see if the symptom is tickled with an older kernel, though I think that's fairly unlikely.  Try the 7.10 desktop cd.
Any idea how it's possible?
I mean, the sound quality is still great.
Don't have a 7.10 lying around iirc.
Perhaps the Alternative CD, but that isn't a fast/easy solution.
sure, there are myriad possibilities from dying HD to dying ac'97 codec...
hmm.  Is the media file on your local HD or on an external usb mass storage device?
First run it was on my HD, now I've copied it to my iPod as to play it back under the Live CD.
hmm, there's a possible usb controller issue, but I don't think it's too likely [yet]
if you play the same song (so that it's cached), is the symptom reproducible?
That would mean both my HD is failing AND my USB ports are fucked.  How likely are both outside of the motherboard just being dead, which isn't the case I assuem since I can still use my PC.
Will try.
Stop > Play.
Thinking perhaps RAM faillure?  Song's playing fine thus far, the stuff it has already played before.
It played back completely this time.  Now I'm totally lost, hehe.
I would not suspect bad RAM.
I would suspect a controller issue if it is in fact reproducible across usb mass storage devices
Ok, and the song played find after having it play to about halfway before.
Which controller?
usb 2.0
That would mean it should play fine over HD, no?
Which as we already found out was not the case.
note that I'm glossing over some issues; it's not necessarily hardware; it can be a kernel issue.  There's at least one known kernel issue with usb 2.0 controllers.
Shall I mount the HD again and play the same song stored there?
and/or try a different one not cached in RAM
Will try both.
Same song, on HD.
Same song, only on HD, plays back fine.  Trying a different song on the HD now.
The different, shorter and lower bitrate, song played back completely.
Questionmarks as to what the heck's happening are growing, hehehe.
Copy?
right
Any ideas?
at this point, because we've ruled out ALSA and PulseAudio, you'd need to do some legwork on patterns
Okay.  No idea what you mean.
I mean that you can see under what conditions the freezes occur.  Only after a fresh boot while playing media from local HD? etc.
Ah, that kind of patterning.
without using systrace, it's a bit difficult for me to continue.
Okay.
sorry, mean systemtap
Don't know that program either, so doesn't make much difference.
Any idea on how it's related to video and those interupting during playback?
I will do some patterning tomorrow.  Going to sleep for now.  Thanks for the help, and good night.
Hello, you there?
